# _The Godfather_

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the 1972 film. For the novel on which the film is based,
see [The Godfather (novel)](/wiki/The_Godfather_\(novel\) "The Godfather
\(novel\)"). For male godparent in many Christian traditions, see
[Godfather](/wiki/Godfather_\(disambiguation\) "Godfather
\(disambiguation\)").

_**The Godfather**_ is a 1972 American [crime film](/wiki/Crime_film "Crime
film") directed by [Francis Ford Coppola](/wiki/Francis_Ford_Coppola "Francis
Ford Coppola") and produced by [Albert S. Ruddy](/wiki/Albert_S._Ruddy "Albert
S. Ruddy"), based on [Mario Puzo](/wiki/Mario_Puzo "Mario Puzo")'s best-
selling [eponymous](/wiki/Eponym "Eponym") novel. It stars [Marlon
Brando](/wiki/Marlon_Brando "Marlon Brando") and [Al Pacino](/wiki/Al_Pacino
"Al Pacino") as the leaders of a fictional New York crime family. The story,
spanning 1945 to 1955, chronicles the [family](/wiki/Corleone_family "Corleone
family") under the patriarch [Vito Corleone](/wiki/Vito_Corleone "Vito
Corleone") (Brando), focusing on the transformation of [Michael
Corleone](/wiki/Michael_Corleone "Michael Corleone") (Pacino) from reluctant
family outsider to ruthless [mafia](/wiki/American_Mafia "American Mafia")
[boss](/wiki/Boss_\(crime\) "Boss \(crime\)").

[Paramount Pictures](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures "Paramount Pictures") obtained
the rights to the novel for the price of $80,000, before it gained popularity.
Studio executives had trouble finding a director; their first few candidates
turned down the position. They and Coppola disagreed over who would play
several characters, in particular, Vito and Michael. Filming was done on
location and completed earlier than scheduled. The musical score was composed
primarily by [Nino Rota](/wiki/Nino_Rota "Nino Rota") with additional pieces
by [Carmine Coppola](/wiki/Carmine_Coppola "Carmine Coppola").

The film was the [highest-grossing film of
1972](/wiki/1972_in_film#Top_grossing_films_.28U.S..29 "1972 in film") and was
for a time the [highest-grossing film ever made](/wiki/List_of_highest-
grossing_films#Timeline_of_highest-grossing_films "List of highest-grossing
films"). It won the [Oscars](/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy Awards") for [Best
Picture](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture "Academy Award for Best
Picture"), [Best Actor](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Actor "Academy Award for
Best Actor") (Brando) and [Best Adapted
Screenplay](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Writing_\(Adapted_Screenplay\)
"Academy Award for Best Writing \(Adapted Screenplay\)") (for Puzo and
Coppola). Its seven other Oscar nominations included Pacino, [James
Caan](/wiki/James_Caan "James Caan"), and [Robert Duvall](/wiki/Robert_Duvall
"Robert Duvall") for [Best Supporting
Actor](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor "Academy Award for Best
Supporting Actor") and Coppola for [Best
Director](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Director "Academy Award for Best
Director").

_The Godfather_ is widely regarded as one of the [greatest films in world
cinema](/wiki/List_of_films_considered_the_best "List of films considered the
best") and one of the most influential, especially in the
[gangster](/wiki/Gangster_film "Gangster film") genre. It was selected for
preservation in the U.S. [National Film Registry](/wiki/National_Film_Registry
"National Film Registry") of the [Library of
Congress](/wiki/Library_of_Congress "Library of Congress") in 1990, being
deemed "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant" and is ranked
the [second-greatest film in American
cinema](/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years...100_Movies_\(10th_Anniversary_Edition\)
"AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies \(10th Anniversary Edition\)") (behind _[Citizen
Kane](/wiki/Citizen_Kane "Citizen Kane")_) by the [American Film
Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American Film Institute"). It was
followed by sequels _[The Godfather Part II](/wiki/The_Godfather_Part_II "The
Godfather Part II")_ (1974) and _[The Godfather Part
III](/wiki/The_Godfather_Part_III "The Godfather Part III")_ (1990).

## Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Plot")]

In 1945, at his daughter Connie's wedding, Vito Corleone hears requests in his
role as the Godfather, the [Don](/wiki/Don_\(honorific\) "Don \(honorific\)")
of a New York crime family. Vito's youngest son,
[Michael](/wiki/Michael_Corleone "Michael Corleone"), who was a
[Marine](/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps "United States Marine Corps") during
[World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), introduces his girlfriend,
[Kay Adams](/wiki/Kay_Adams-Corleone "Kay Adams-Corleone"), to his family at
the reception. Johnny Fontane, a famous singer and Vito's
[godson](/wiki/Godparent "Godparent"), seeks Vito's help in securing a movie
role; Vito dispatches his [consigliere](/wiki/Consigliere "Consigliere"), [Tom
Hagen](/wiki/Tom_Hagen "Tom Hagen"), to Los Angeles to persuade the obnoxious
studio head, Jack Woltz, to give Johnny the part. Woltz refuses until he wakes
up in bed with the severed head of his prized [stallion](/wiki/Stud_\(animal\)
"Stud \(animal\)").

Shortly before Christmas, drug baron Virgil "The Turk" Sollozzo, backed by the
Tattaglia crime family, asks Vito for investment in his narcotics business and
protection through his political connections. Wary of involvement in a
dangerous new trade that risks alienating political insiders, Vito declines.
Suspicious, Vito sends his enforcer, [Luca Brasi](/wiki/Luca_Brasi "Luca
Brasi"), to spy on them. However, a Tattaglia button man
[garrotes](/wiki/Garrote "Garrote") Brasi during Brasi's first meeting with
Bruno Tattaglia and Sollozzo. Later Sollozzo has Vito gunned down in the
street, then kidnaps Hagen. With Corleone first-born
[Sonny](/wiki/Sonny_Corleone "Sonny Corleone") in command, Sollozzo pressures
Hagen to persuade Sonny to accept Sollozzo's deal, then releases him. The
family receives fish wrapped in Brasi's bullet-proof vest, indicating that
Luca "sleeps with the fishes." Vito survives, and at the hospital Michael
thwarts another attempt on his father; Michael's jaw is broken by
[NYPD](/wiki/NYPD "NYPD") Captain Marc McCluskey, Sollozzo's bodyguard. Sonny
retaliates with a [hit](/wiki/Contract_killing "Contract killing") on Bruno
Tattaglia. Michael plots to murder Sollozzo and McCluskey: on the pretext of
settling the dispute, Michael agrees to meet them in a [Bronx](/wiki/The_Bronx
"The Bronx") restaurant. There, retrieving a planted handgun, he kills both
men.

Despite a clampdown by the authorities, the [Five
Families](/wiki/Five_Families_\(The_Godfather\) "Five Families \(The
Godfather\)") erupt in open warfare and Vito's sons fear for their safety.
Michael takes refuge in [Sicily](/wiki/Sicily "Sicily") and
[Fredo](/wiki/Fredo_Corleone "Fredo Corleone") is sheltered by Moe Greene in
[Las Vegas](/wiki/Las_Vegas_metropolitan_area "Las Vegas metropolitan area").
Sonny attacks his brother-in-law Carlo on the street for abusing his sister
and threatens to kill him if it happens again. When it does, Sonny speeds to
their home, but is ambushed at a highway toll booth and riddled with
submachine gun fire. While in Sicily, Michael meets and marries Apollonia
Vitelli, but a car bomb intended for him takes her life.

Devastated by Sonny's death, Vito moves to end the feuds. Realizing that the
Tattaglias are controlled by the now-dominant Don [Emilio
Barzini](/wiki/Emilio_Barzini "Emilio Barzini"), Vito assures the Five
Families that he will withdraw his opposition to their heroin business and
forgo avenging his son's murder. His safety guaranteed, Michael returns home
to enter the family business and marry Kay, who gives birth to two children by
the early 1950s.

With his father at the end of his career and his brother too weak, Michael
takes the family reins, promising his wife the business will be legitimate
within five years. To that end, he insists Hagen relocate to Las Vegas and
relinquish his role to Vito because Tom is not a "wartime consigliere"; Vito
agrees Tom should "have no part in what will happen" in the coming battles
with rival families. When Michael travels to Las Vegas to buy out Greene's
stake in the family's casinos, their partner derides the Corleones for being
run out of New York; Michael is dismayed to see that Fredo has fallen under
Greene's sway.

Vito suffers a fatal [heart attack](/wiki/Myocardial_infarction "Myocardial
infarction"). At the funeral, [Tessio](/wiki/Salvatore_Tessio "Salvatore
Tessio"), a Corleone [capo](/wiki/Caporegime "Caporegime"), asks Michael to
meet with Don Barzini, signalling the betrayal that Vito had forewarned. The
meeting is set for the same day as the christening of Connie’s baby. While
Michael stands at the altar as the child's godfather, Corleone assassins
murder the other New York dons and Moe Greene. Tessio is executed for his
treachery and Michael extracts Carlo’s confession to his complicity in setting
up Sonny's murder for Barzini. A Corleone capo,
[Clemenza](/wiki/Peter_Clemenza "Peter Clemenza"), garrotes Carlo with a wire.
Connie accuses Michael of the murder, telling Kay that Michael ordered all the
killings. Kay is relieved when Michael finally denies it, but, when the capos
arrive, they address her husband as Don Corleone, and she watches as they
close the door on her.

## Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Cast")]

[![A screenshot of Michael and Vito Corleone during The
Godfather](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b7/TheGodfatherAlPacinoMarlonBrando.jpg/220px-
TheGodfatherAlPacinoMarlonBrando.jpg)](/wiki/File:TheGodfatherAlPacinoMarlonBrando.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:TheGodfatherAlPacinoMarlonBrando.jpg "Enlarge")

Al Pacino as Michael Corleone  
Marlon Brando as Vito Corleone

  * [Marlon Brando](/wiki/Marlon_Brando "Marlon Brando"), in the title role, is [Vito Corleone](/wiki/Vito_Corleone "Vito Corleone") (born Vito Andolini), the [Don](/wiki/Crime_boss "Crime boss") of the [Corleone crime family](/wiki/Corleone_family "Corleone family"). A native [Sicilian](/wiki/Sicily "Sicily"), he is married to Carmela Corleone and the father of Tom (adoptive), Sonny, Fredo, Michael, and Connie.
  * [Al Pacino](/wiki/Al_Pacino "Al Pacino") as [Michael Corleone](/wiki/Michael_Corleone "Michael Corleone"), the Don's third son, recently returned from World War II. The only college-educated family member, he is initially steered from the family business. His progression from the family's last-born son to its ruthless boss is the main subject matter of the film.
  * [James Caan](/wiki/James_Caan "James Caan") as [Santino "Sonny" Corleone](/wiki/Sonny_Corleone "Sonny Corleone"), Don Corleone's hot-headed eldest son. As [underboss](/wiki/Underboss "Underboss"), he is the heir-apparent to succeed his father as head of the Corleone family.
  * [Robert Duvall](/wiki/Robert_Duvall "Robert Duvall") as [Tom Hagen](/wiki/Tom_Hagen "Tom Hagen"), Don Corleone's informally [adopted](/wiki/Adoption "Adoption") son, he is the family lawyer and _[consigliere](/wiki/Consigliere "Consigliere")_. Unlike the Corleones, he is of [German](/wiki/German-American "German-American")-[Irish](/wiki/Irish-American "Irish-American") descent, not Sicilian.
  * [Diane Keaton](/wiki/Diane_Keaton "Diane Keaton") as [Kay Adams-Corleone](/wiki/Kay_Adams-Corleone "Kay Adams-Corleone"), Michael's non-[Italian](/wiki/Italian-American "Italian-American") girlfriend and his second wife and mother of his two children.
  * [John Cazale](/wiki/John_Cazale "John Cazale") as [Frederico "Fredo" Corleone](/wiki/Fredo_Corleone "Fredo Corleone"), the middle son of the Corleone family. Deeply insecure and not very bright, he is considered the weakest Corleone brother.
  * [Talia Shire](/wiki/Talia_Shire "Talia Shire") as [Constanzia "Connie" Corleone](/wiki/Connie_Corleone "Connie Corleone"), the youngest child and only daughter of the Corleone family. Her wedding reception begins the film.
  * [Gianni Russo](/wiki/Gianni_Russo "Gianni Russo") as Carlo Rizzi, Connie's abusive husband. Introduced to the Corleone family by Sonny, whom he ultimately betrays to the Barzini family.
  * [Richard S. Castellano](/wiki/Richard_S._Castellano "Richard S. Castellano") as [Peter Clemenza](/wiki/Peter_Clemenza "Peter Clemenza"), a [caporegime](/wiki/Caporegime "Caporegime") for the Corleone family. He is an old friend of Vito Corleone and Salvatore Tessio.
  * [Abe Vigoda](/wiki/Abe_Vigoda "Abe Vigoda") as [Salvatore Tessio](/wiki/Salvatore_Tessio "Salvatore Tessio"), a caporegime for the Corleone family. He is an old friend of Vito Corleone and Peter Clemenza.
  * [Al Lettieri](/wiki/Al_Lettieri "Al Lettieri") as Virgil "The Turk" Sollozzo, a heroin [dealer](/wiki/Drug_dealer "Drug dealer") associated with the Tattaglia family. He seeks both financial investment and the protection of the Tattaglia family's narcotics business through Don Corleone's political connections.
  * [Sterling Hayden](/wiki/Sterling_Hayden "Sterling Hayden") as [Captain Mark McCluskey](/wiki/Captain_McCluskey_\(The_Godfather\) "Captain McCluskey \(The Godfather\)"), a [corrupt](/wiki/Police_corruption "Police corruption") NYPD police captain on Sollozzo's [payroll](/wiki/Payroll "Payroll").
  * [Lenny Montana](/wiki/Lenny_Montana "Lenny Montana") as [Luca Brasi](/wiki/Luca_Brasi "Luca Brasi"), Vito Corleone's [enforcer](/wiki/Mob_enforcer "Mob enforcer").
  * [Richard Conte](/wiki/Richard_Conte "Richard Conte") as [Emilio Barzini](/wiki/Emilio_Barzini "Emilio Barzini"), Don of the Barzini family.
  * [Al Martino](/wiki/Al_Martino "Al Martino") as Johnny Fontane, a world-famous singer and Vito's [godson](/wiki/Godson "Godson"). The character is loosely based on [Frank Sinatra](/wiki/Frank_Sinatra "Frank Sinatra").
  * [John Marley](/wiki/John_Marley "John Marley") as Jack Woltz, a powerful Hollywood producer.
  * [Alex Rocco](/wiki/Alex_Rocco "Alex Rocco") as Moe Greene, a longtime associate of the Corleone family who owns a Las Vegas hotel. The character is based on [Bugsy Siegel](/wiki/Bugsy_Siegel "Bugsy Siegel").
  * [Morgana King](/wiki/Morgana_King "Morgana King") as [Carmela Corleone](/wiki/Carmela_Corleone "Carmela Corleone"), Vito's wife and mother of Sonny, Fredo, Michael, and Connie, and adoptive mother to [Tom Hagen](/wiki/Tom_Hagen "Tom Hagen").
  * Salvatore Corsitto as [Amerigo Bonasera](/wiki/Amerigo_Bonasera "Amerigo Bonasera"), a mortician who, in the opening scene, asks Don Corleone for revenge against two boys who severely beat and attempted to rape his daughter.
  * [Corrado Gaipa](/wiki/Corrado_Gaipa "Corrado Gaipa") as Don Tommasino, an old friend of Vito Corleone, who shelters Michael during his [exile](/wiki/Exile "Exile") in Sicily.
  * [Franco Citti](/wiki/Franco_Citti "Franco Citti") as Calò, Michael's bodyguard in Sicily.
  * [Angelo Infanti](/wiki/Angelo_Infanti "Angelo Infanti") as Fabrizio, Michael's bodyguard in Sicily. He helped set up the assassination attempt on Michael that kills Apollonia.
  * [Johnny Martino](/wiki/Johnny_Martino "Johnny Martino") as Paulie Gatto, a soldier under Peter Clemenza and Vito's driver. He is executed for his part in the assassination attempt on Vito.
  * [Victor Rendina](/wiki/Victor_Rendina "Victor Rendina") as Philip Tattaglia, Don of the Tattaglia family.
  * [Tony Giorgio](/wiki/Tony_Giorgio_\(actor\) "Tony Giorgio \(actor\)") as Bruno Tattaglia, Philip Tattaglia's son and [underboss](/wiki/Underboss "Underboss") of the Tattaglia family. Sonny Corleone has him assassinated in retaliation for the shooting of Vito Corleone.
  * [Simonetta Stefanelli](/wiki/Simonetta_Stefanelli "Simonetta Stefanelli") as [Apollonia Vitelli-Corleone](/wiki/Apollonia_Vitelli-Corleone "Apollonia Vitelli-Corleone"), a young woman Michael meets and marries while in Sicily. She is killed a few months later in an assassination attempt on Michael.
  * [Rudy Bond](/wiki/Rudy_Bond "Rudy Bond") as Don Cuneo, head of the New York-based [Cuneo family](/wiki/Cuneo_family "Cuneo family").
  * [Louis Guss](/wiki/Louis_Guss "Louis Guss") as Don Zaluchi, Don of the Zaluchi family of Detroit.
  * [Tom Rosqui](/wiki/Tom_Rosqui "Tom Rosqui") as Rocco Lampone, a soldier under Clemenza who eventually becomes a caporegime in the Corleone family.
  * [Joe Spinell](/wiki/Joe_Spinell "Joe Spinell") as Willi Cicci, a soldier in the Corleone family.
  * [Richard Bright](/wiki/Richard_Bright_\(actor\) "Richard Bright \(actor\)") as [Al Neri](/wiki/Al_Neri "Al Neri"), Michael Corleone's personal bodyguard and hitman who eventually becomes a caporegime.
  * [Julie Gregg](/wiki/Julie_Gregg "Julie Gregg") as [Sandra Corleone](/wiki/Sandra_Corleone "Sandra Corleone"), Sonny's wife and later widow, and the mother of their four children.
  * [Jeannie Linero](/wiki/Jeannie_Linero "Jeannie Linero") as [Lucy Mancini](/wiki/Lucy_Mancini "Lucy Mancini"), Sonny's mistress.
  * [Sofia Coppola](/wiki/Sofia_Coppola "Sofia Coppola") (_uncredited_) as infant Michael Francis Rizzi, the nephew and godson of Michael Corleone.

## Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

### Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Development")]

The film is based on [Mario Puzo](/wiki/Mario_Puzo "Mario Puzo")'s _[The
Godfather](/wiki/The_Godfather_\(novel\) "The Godfather \(novel\)")_ ; a novel
that remained on [_The New York Times_ Best Seller
list](/wiki/The_New_York_Times_Best_Seller_list "The New York Times Best
Seller list") for 67 weeks and sold over nine million copies in two
years.[5][6][7] Published in 1969, it became the best selling published work
in history for several years.[8] [Paramount Pictures](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures
"Paramount Pictures") originally found out about Puzo's novel in 1967 when a
literary scout for the company contacted then Paramount Vice President of
Production [Peter Bart](/wiki/Peter_Bart "Peter Bart") about Puzo's sixty-page
unfinished manuscript.[6] Bart believed the work was "much beyond a Mafia
story" and offered Puzo a $12,500 option for the work, with an option for
$80,000 if the finished work were made into a film.[6][9] Despite Puzo's agent
telling him to turn down the offer, Puzo was desperate for money and accepted
the deal.[6][9] Paramount's [Robert Evans](/wiki/Robert_Evans "Robert Evans")
relates that, when they met in early 1968, it was he who offered Puzo the
$12,500 deal for the 60-page manuscript titled _Mafia_ after the author
confided in him that he urgently needed $10,000 to pay off gambling debts.[10]

In March 1967, Paramount announced that they backed Puzo's upcoming work in
the hopes of making a film.[6] In 1969, Paramount confirmed their intentions
to make a film out of the novel for the price of $80,000,[N 1][9][11][12][13]
with aims to have the film released on Christmas Day in 1971.[14] On March 23,
1970, [Albert S. Ruddy](/wiki/Albert_S._Ruddy "Albert S. Ruddy") was
officially announced as the film's producer, in part because studio executives
were impressed with his interview and because he was known for bringing his
films in under budget.[15][16][17]

### Direction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Direction")]

[![A photo of Francis Ford
Coppola](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Francis_Ford_Coppola_2011_CC.jpg/220px-
Francis_Ford_Coppola_2011_CC.jpg)](/wiki/File:Francis_Ford_Coppola_2011_CC.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Francis_Ford_Coppola_2011_CC.jpg "Enlarge")

[Francis Ford Coppola](/wiki/Francis_Ford_Coppola "Francis Ford Coppola") was
selected as director, as Paramount wanted the picture to be directed by an
[Italian American](/wiki/Italian_American "Italian American") to make the film
"ethnic to the core".

Evans wanted the picture to be directed by an [Italian
American](/wiki/Italian_American "Italian American") to make the film "ethnic
to the core".[18][19] Paramount's latest mafia based movie, _[The
Brotherhood](/wiki/The_Brotherhood_\(1968_film\) "The Brotherhood \(1968
film\)")_ , had been a box office bomb;[7][20] Evans believed that the reason
for its failure was its almost complete lack of cast members or creative
personnel of Italian descent (the director [Martin Ritt](/wiki/Martin_Ritt
"Martin Ritt") and star [Kirk Douglas](/wiki/Kirk_Douglas "Kirk Douglas") were
both Jewish).[10] [Sergio Leone](/wiki/Sergio_Leone "Sergio Leone") was
Paramount's first choice to direct the film.[21][22] Leone turned down the
option to work on his own gangster film _[Once Upon a Time in
America](/wiki/Once_Upon_a_Time_in_America "Once Upon a Time in
America")_.[21][22] [Peter Bogdanovich](/wiki/Peter_Bogdanovich "Peter
Bogdanovich") was then approached but he also declined the offer because he
was not interested in the mafia.[23][24][25] In addition, [Peter
Yates](/wiki/Peter_Yates "Peter Yates"), [Richard Brooks](/wiki/Richard_Brooks
"Richard Brooks"), [Arthur Penn](/wiki/Arthur_Penn "Arthur Penn"), [Costa-
Gavras](/wiki/Costa-Gavras "Costa-Gavras"), and [Otto
Preminger](/wiki/Otto_Preminger "Otto Preminger") were all offered the
position and declined.[26][27] Evans' chief assistant Peter Bart suggested
[Francis Ford Coppola](/wiki/Francis_Ford_Coppola "Francis Ford Coppola"), as
a director of Italian ancestry who would work for a low sum and budget after
the poor reception of his latest film _[The Rain People](/wiki/The_Rain_People
"The Rain People")_.[28][18] Coppola initially turned down the job because he
found Puzo's novel sleazy and sensationalist, describing it as "pretty cheap
stuff".[10][29] At the time Coppola's studio, [American
Zoetrope](/wiki/American_Zoetrope "American Zoetrope"), owed over $400,000 to
[Warner Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Bros. "Warner Bros.") for budget overruns with the
film _[THX 1138](/wiki/THX_1138 "THX 1138")_ and when coupled with his poor
financial standing, along with advice from friends and family, Coppola
reversed his initial decision and took the job.[27][30][31] Coppola was
officially announced as director of the film on September 28, 1970.[32]
Paramount had offered twelve other directors the job with _The Godfather_
before Coppola agreed.[33] Coppola agreed to receive $125,000 and six percent
of the gross rentals.[34][35]

#### Coppola and
Paramount[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Coppola and Paramount")]

Before _The Godfather_ was in production, Paramount had been going through an
unsuccessful period.[7] In addition to the failure of _The Brotherhood_ , the
studio had usurped their budget for their recent films: _[Darling
Lili](/wiki/Darling_Lili "Darling Lili")_ ,[16] _[Paint Your
Wagon](/wiki/Paint_Your_Wagon_\(film\) "Paint Your Wagon \(film\)")_ , and
_[Waterloo](/wiki/Waterloo_\(1970_film\) "Waterloo \(1970 film\)")_.[7][20]
The budget for the film was originally $2.5 million but as the book grew in
popularity Coppola argued for and ultimately received a larger budget.[N
2][26][36][38] Paramount executives wanted the movie to be set in then modern-
day [Kansas City](/wiki/Kansas_City "Kansas City") and shot in the studio
backlot in order to cut down on costs.[26][16][36] Coppola objected and wanted
to set the movie in the same time period as its eponymous novel, the 1940s and
1950s;[26][31][16][32] Coppola's reasons included: Michael Corleone's Marine
Corps stint, the emergence of corporate America, and America in the years
after World War II.[32] The executives eventually agreed to Coppola's wish as
the novel became increasingly successful.[36][16] The studio heads
subsequently let Coppola film on location in New York City and Sicily.[41]

Gulf & Western executive [Charles Bluhdorn](/wiki/Charles_Bluhdorn "Charles
Bluhdorn") was frustrated with Coppola over the number of screen tests he had
performed without finding a person to play the various roles.[39] Production
quickly fell behind because of Coppola's indecisiveness and conflicts with
Paramount, which led to costs being around $40,000 per day.[39] With the
rising costs, Paramount had then Vice President Jack Ballard keep a close eye
on production costs.[42] While filming, Coppola stated that he felt he could
be fired at any point as he knew Paramount executives were not happy with many
of the decisions he had made.[26] Coppola was aware that Evans had asked [Elia
Kazan](/wiki/Elia_Kazan "Elia Kazan") to take over directing the film, because
he feared that Coppola was too inexperienced to cope with the increased size
of the production.[43] Coppola was also convinced that the film editor, [Aram
Avakian](/wiki/Aram_Avakian "Aram Avakian"), and the assistant director, Steve
Kestner, were conspiring to get him fired. Avakian complained to Evans that he
could not edit the scenes correctly because Coppola was not shooting enough
footage. Evans however was satisfied with the footage being sent to the west
coast, and authorized Coppola to fire them both. Coppola later explained:
"Like the godfather, I fired people as a preemptory strike. The people who
were angling the most to have me fired, I had fired."[44] Brando threatened
that he would quit if Coppola were fired.[26][42]

Paramount wanted _The Godfather_ to appeal to a wide audience and threatened
Coppola with a "violence coach" to make the film more exciting. Coppola added
a few more violent scenes to keep the studio happy. The scene in which Connie
smashes [crockery](/wiki/Tableware "Tableware") after finding out Carlo has
been cheating was added for this reason.[31]

### Writing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Writing")]

On April 14, 1970, it was revealed that Puzo was hired by Paramount for
$100,000, along with a percentage of the film's profits, to work on the
screenplay for the film.[45][46][17] Working from the book, Coppola wanted to
have the themes of culture, character, power, and family at the forefront of
the film, whereas Puzo wanted to retain aspects from his novel[47] and his
initial draft of 150 pages was finished on August 10, 1970.[45][46] After
Coppola was hired as director, both Puzo and Coppola worked on the screenplay,
but separately.[48] Puzo worked on his draft in Los Angeles, while Coppola
wrote his version in [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco").[48]
Coppola created a book where he tore pages out of Puzo's book and pasted them
into the book.[48] There, he made notes about each of the book's fifty scenes,
which related to major themes prevalent in the scene, whether the scene should
be included in the film, along with ideas and concepts that could be used when
filming to make the film true to Italian culture.[48][42] The two remained in
contact while they wrote their respective screenplays and made decisions on
what to include and what to remove for the final version.[48] A second draft
was completed on March 1, 1971, and was 173 pages long.[45][49] The final
screenplay was finished on March 29, 1971,[46] wound up being 163 pages
long,[48][45] 40 pages over what Paramount had asked for.[50] When filming,
Coppola referred to the notebook he had created over the final draft of the
screenplay.[48][42] Screenwriter [Robert Towne](/wiki/Robert_Towne "Robert
Towne") did uncredited work on the script, particularly on the Pacino-Brando
garden scene.[51] Despite finishing the third draft, some scenes in the film
were still not written yet and were written during production.[52]

The Italian-American Civil Rights League wanted all uses of the words "mafia"
and "Cosa Nostra" to be removed from the script, in addition to feeling that
the film emphasized stereotypes about Italian-Americans.[14][53][54][55] The
league also requested that all the money earned from the premiere be donated
to the league's fund to build a new hospital.[54][55] Coppola claimed that
Puzo's screenplay only contained two instances of the word "mafia" being used,
while "Cosa Nostra" was not used at all.[54][55] Those two uses were removed
and replaced with other terms, which Coppola felt did not change the story at
all.[54][55] The league eventually gave its support for the script.[54][55]

### Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Casting")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Al_Pacino_-
_Hummel.jpg/220px-Al_Pacino_-_Hummel.jpg)](/wiki/File:Al_Pacino_-_Hummel.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Al_Pacino_-_Hummel.jpg "Enlarge")

[Al Pacino](/wiki/Al_Pacino "Al Pacino") (pictured above in _[The Basic
Training of Pavlo Hummel](/wiki/The_Basic_Training_of_Pavlo_Hummel "The Basic
Training of Pavlo Hummel")_) was chosen to portray [Michael
Corleone](/wiki/Michael_Corleone "Michael Corleone")

Puzo was first to show interest in having [Marlon Brando](/wiki/Marlon_Brando
"Marlon Brando") portray Don Vito Corleone by sending a letter to Brando in
which he stated Brando was the "only actor who can play the Godfather."[56]
Despite Puzo's wishes, the executives at Paramount were against having Brando
play the part due to the poor success of his recent films and his short
temper.[57][36] Coppola favored Brando or [Laurence
Olivier](/wiki/Laurence_Olivier "Laurence Olivier") for the role,[58][59] but
Olivier's agent refused the role claiming Olivier was sick;[60] however,
Olivier went on to star in _[Sleuth](/wiki/Sleuth_\(1972_film\) "Sleuth \(1972
film\)")_ later that year.[59] The studio mainly pushed for [Ernest
Borgnine](/wiki/Ernest_Borgnine "Ernest Borgnine") to receive the part.[58]
Other considerations were [George C. Scott](/wiki/George_C._Scott "George C.
Scott"), [Richard Conte](/wiki/Richard_Conte "Richard Conte"), [Anthony
Quinn](/wiki/Anthony_Quinn "Anthony Quinn"), and [Orson
Welles](/wiki/Orson_Welles "Orson Welles").[61][58][62]

After months of debate between Coppola and Paramount over Brando, the two
finalists for the role were Borgnine and Brando,[63] the latter of which
Paramount president [Stanley Jaffe](/wiki/Stanley_Jaffe "Stanley Jaffe")
required to perform a screen test.[64][65] Coppola did not want to offend
Brando and stated that he needed to test equipment in order to set up the
screen test at Brando's [California](/wiki/California "California")
residence.[65][66] For make-up, Brando stuck cotton balls in his cheeks,[63]
put shoe polish in his hair to darken it, and rolled his collar.[67] Coppola
placed Brando's audition tape in the middle of the videos of the audition
tapes as the Paramount executives watched them.[68] The executives were
impressed with Brando's efforts and allowed Coppola to cast Brando for the
role if Brando accepted a lower salary and put up a bond to ensure he would
not cause any delays in production.[63][68][69]

From the start of production, Coppola wanted [Robert
Duvall](/wiki/Robert_Duvall "Robert Duvall") to play the part of Tom
Hagen.[14][70][71] After screen testing several other actors, Coppola
eventually got his wish and Duvall was awarded the part of Tom Hagen.[70][71]
[Al Martino](/wiki/Al_Martino "Al Martino"), a then famed singer in
nightclubs, was notified of the character Johnny Fontane by a friend who read
the eponymous novel and felt Martino represented the character of Johnny
Fontane.[18] Martino then contacted producer [Al Ruddy](/wiki/Al_Ruddy "Al
Ruddy"), who gave him the part.[18] However, Martino was stripped of the part
after Coppola became director and then awarded the role to Italian singer [Vic
Damone](/wiki/Vic_Damone "Vic Damone").[18] Damone eventually dropped the role
because he did not want to play an anti-Italian American character, in
addition to being paid too little.[72] According to Martino, after being
stripped of the role, he went to his godfather and crime boss Russ Bufalino
who then orchestrated the publication of various news articles that talked of
how Coppola was unaware of Ruddy giving Martino the part; that, when coupled
with pressure from the mafia who felt Martino deserved the role, led Damone to
quit as Fontane.[18] Either way, the part of Johnny Fontane ended up with
Martino.[18][72]

[![A picture of James
Caan.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/James_Caan_%281976%29.jpg/220px-
James_Caan_%281976%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:James_Caan_\(1976\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:James_Caan_\(1976\).jpg "Enlarge")

[James Caan](/wiki/James_Caan "James Caan") (pictured in 1976) was chosen to
play [Sonny Corleone](/wiki/Sonny_Corleone "Sonny Corleone")

[Robert De Niro](/wiki/Robert_De_Niro "Robert De Niro") originally was given
the part of Paulie Gatto.[73][63] A spot in _[The Gang That Couldn't Shoot
Straight](/wiki/The_Gang_That_Couldn%27t_Shoot_Straight_\(film\) "The Gang
That Couldn't Shoot Straight \(film\)")_ opened up after Al Pacino quit the
project in favor of _The Godfather_ , which led De Niro to audition for the
role and leave _The Godfather_ after receiving the part.[73][74] After De Niro
quit, [Johnny Martino](/wiki/Johnny_Martino "Johnny Martino") was given the
role of Gatto.[18] Coppola cast [Diane Keaton](/wiki/Diane_Keaton "Diane
Keaton") for the role of Kay Adams due to her reputation for being
[eccentric](/wiki/Eccentricity_\(behavior\) "Eccentricity \(behavior\)").[75]
[John Cazale](/wiki/John_Cazale "John Cazale") was given the part of Fredo
Corleone after Coppola saw him perform in an Off Broadway production.[75]
[Gianni Russo](/wiki/Gianni_Russo "Gianni Russo") was given the role of Carlo
Rizzi after he was asked to perform a screen test in which he acted out the
fight between Rizzi and Connie.[76]

Nearing the start of filming on March 29, [Michael
Corleone](/wiki/Michael_Corleone "Michael Corleone") had yet to be cast.[77]
Paramount executives wanted a popular actor, either [Warren
Beatty](/wiki/Warren_Beatty "Warren Beatty") or [Robert
Redford](/wiki/Robert_Redford "Robert Redford").[78][63][79] Producer Robert
Evans wanted [Ryan O'Neal](/wiki/Ryan_O%27Neal "Ryan O'Neal") to receive the
role in part due to his recent success in _[Love
Story](/wiki/Love_Story_\(1970_film\) "Love Story \(1970 film\)")_.[79][80]
Pacino was Coppola's favorite for the role as he could picture him roaming the
Sicilian countryside, and wanted an unknown actor who looked like an Italian-
American.[31][79][80] However, Paramount executives found Pacino to be too
short to play Michael.[14][18] [Dustin Hoffman](/wiki/Dustin_Hoffman "Dustin
Hoffman"), [Martin Sheen](/wiki/Martin_Sheen "Martin Sheen"), and [James
Caan](/wiki/James_Caan "James Caan") also auditioned.[75] Caan was well
received by the Paramount executives and was given the part of Michael
initially, while the role of [Sonny Corleone](/wiki/Sonny_Corleone "Sonny
Corleone") was awarded to [Carmine Caridi](/wiki/Carmine_Caridi "Carmine
Caridi").[18] Coppola still pushed for Pacino to play Michael after the fact
and Evans eventually conceded, allowing Pacino to have the role of Michael as
long as Caan played Sonny.[81] Evans preferred Caan over Caridi because Caan
was seven inches shorter than Caridi, which was much closer to Pacino's
height.[18] Despite agreeing to play Michael Corleone, Pacino was contracted
to star in MGM's _The Gang That Couldn 't Shoot Straight_, but the two studios
agreed on a settlement and Pacino was signed by Paramount three weeks before
shooting began.[82]

Coppola gave several roles in the film to family members.[18] He gave his
sister, [Talia Shire](/wiki/Talia_Shire "Talia Shire"), the role of Connie
Corleone.[83][84] His daughter [Sofia](/wiki/Sofia_Coppola "Sofia Coppola")
played Michael Francis Rizzi, Connie's and Carlo's newborn son.[18][85]
[Carmine Coppola](/wiki/Carmine_Coppola "Carmine Coppola"), his father,
appeared in the film as an extra playing a piano during a scene.[86] Coppola's
wife, mother, and two sons all appeared as extras in the picture.[18] Several
smaller roles, like [Luca Brasi](/wiki/Luca_Brasi "Luca Brasi"), were cast
after the filming had started.[87]

### Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Filming")]

Before the filming began, the cast received a two-week period for rehearsal,
which included a dinner where each actor and actress had to assume character
for its duration.[88] Filming was scheduled to begin on March 29, 1971, with
the scene between Michael Corleone and Kay Adams as they leave [Best &
Co.](/wiki/Best_%26_Co. "Best & Co.") in New York City after shopping for
Christmas gifts.[89][90] The weather on March 23 predicted snow flurries,
which caused Ruddy to move the filming date forward; however snow never
materialized and a snow machine was used.[90] Principal filming in New York
continued until July 2, 1971.[91][92] Coppola asked for a three-week break
before heading overseas to film in Sicily.[91] Following the crew's departure
for Sicily, Paramount announced that the release date would be moved from
December to spring 1972.[93]

[![The New York Supreme Court building on Foley Square in Manhattan, New York
City.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/NYC_-
_New_York_County_Supreme_Courthouse.jpg/220px-NYC_-
_New_York_County_Supreme_Courthouse.jpg)](/wiki/File:NYC_-
_New_York_County_Supreme_Courthouse.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NYC_-_New_York_County_Supreme_Courthouse.jpg "Enlarge")

The Don Barzini assassination scene was filmed on the steps of the [New York
Supreme Court](/wiki/New_York_Supreme_Court "New York Supreme Court") building
on [Foley Square](/wiki/Foley_Square "Foley Square") in
[Manhattan](/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan")[94]

Cinematographer [Gordon Willis](/wiki/Gordon_Willis "Gordon Willis") initially
turned down the opportunity to film _The Godfather_ because the production
seemed "chaotic" to him.[95][81] After Willis later accepted the offer, he and
Coppola agreed to not use any modern filming devices, helicopters, or zoom
lenses.[96] Willis and Coppola chose to use a "tableau format" of filming to
make it seem if it was viewed like a painting.[96] He made use of shadows and
low light levels throughout the film to showcase psychological
developments.[96] Willis and Coppola agreed to interplay light and dark scenes
throughout the film.[39] Willis underexposed the film in order to create a
"yellow tone."[96] The scenes in Sicily were shot to display the countryside
and "display a more romantic land," giving these scenes a "softer, more
romantic" feel than the New York scenes.[97]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Vintage_Grill_%26_Car_Museum_May_2017_10_%281941_Packard_Super_Eight_from_The_Godfather%29.jpg/220px-
Vintage_Grill_%26_Car_Museum_May_2017_10_%281941_Packard_Super_Eight_from_The_Godfather%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vintage_Grill_%26_Car_Museum_May_2017_10_\(1941_Packard_Super_Eight_from_The_Godfather\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vintage_Grill_%26_Car_Museum_May_2017_10_\(1941_Packard_Super_Eight_from_The_Godfather\).jpg
"Enlarge")

1941 [Packard Super Eight](/wiki/Packard_Super_Eight "Packard Super Eight")
featured in _The Godfather_

One of the film's most shocking moments involved an actual, severed, horse's
head.[31][98] Coppola received some criticism for the scene, although the head
was obtained from a dog-food company from a horse that was to be killed
regardless of the film.[99] On June 22, the scene where Sonny is killed was
shot on a runway at [Mitchel Field](/wiki/Mitchel_Air_Force_Base "Mitchel Air
Force Base") in Mineola, where three tollbooths were built, along with guard
rails, and billboards to set the scene.[100] Sonny's car was a 1941 Lincoln
Continental with holes drilled in it to resemble bullet holes.[101][102] The
scene took three days to film and cost over $100,000.[103][102]

Coppola's request to film on location was observed; approximately 90 percent
was shot in New York City and its surrounding suburbs,[104][105] using over
120 unique locations.[106] Several scenes were filmed at the Filmways Studio
in [East Harlem](/wiki/East_Harlem "East Harlem").[107] The remaining portions
were filmed in California, or on-site in Sicily, except for the scenes set in
[Las Vegas](/wiki/Las_Vegas "Las Vegas") because there were insufficient funds
to travel there.[108][104] [Savoca](/wiki/Savoca "Savoca") and [Forza
d'Agrò](/wiki/Forza_d%27Agr%C3%B2 "Forza d'Agrò") were the Sicilian towns
featured in the film.[109] The opening wedding scene was shot in a [Staten
Island](/wiki/Staten_Island "Staten Island") neighborhood using almost 750
locals as extras.[105][110] The house used as the Corleone household and the
wedding location was at 110 Longfellow Road in the [Todt Hill](/wiki/Todt_Hill
"Todt Hill") neighborhood of Staten Island.[110][111] The wall around the
Corleone compound was made from [styrofoam](/wiki/Styrofoam "Styrofoam").[110]
Scenes set in and around the Corleone olive oil business were filmed on [Mott
Street](/wiki/Mott_Street "Mott Street").[106][112]

After filming had ended on August 7,[113] post-production efforts were focused
on trimming the film to a manageable length.[114] In addition, producers and
director were still including and removing different scenes from the end
product, along with trimming certain sequences.[115] In September, the first
rough cut of the film was viewed.[114] Of the scenes removed from the film,
many were centered around Sonny because they did not advance the plot.[116] By
November, Coppola and Ruddy finished the semifinal cut.[116] Debates over
personnel involved with the final editing remained even 25 years after the
release of the film.[117] The film began to be shown to Paramount staff and
exhibitors in late December and going into the new year.[118]

Coppola hired Italian composer [Nino Rota](/wiki/Nino_Rota "Nino Rota") to
create the underscore for the film, including the main theme, "[Speak Softly
Love](/wiki/Speak_Softly_Love "Speak Softly Love")".[119][120] For the score,
Rota was to relate to the situations and characters in the film.[119][120]
Rota synthesized new music for the film and took some parts from his
_[Fortunella](/wiki/Fortunella_\(film\) "Fortunella \(film\)")_ score, in
order to create an Italian feel and evoke the tragic film's themes.[121]
Paramount executive Evans found the score to be too "highbrow" and did not
want to use it; however, it was used after Coppola managed to get Evans to
agree.[119][120] Coppola believed that Rota's musical piece gave the film even
more of an Italian feel.[120] Coppola's father,
[Carmine](/wiki/Carmine_Coppola "Carmine Coppola"), created some additional
music for the film,[122] particularly the music played by the band during the
opening wedding scene.[120][121] There are a total of nine instances within
the film where incidental music can be heard.[121]

There was a soundtrack released for the film in 1972 in vinyl form by
[Paramount Records](/wiki/Paramount_Records_\(1969\) "Paramount Records
\(1969\)"), on CD in 1991 by [Geffen Records](/wiki/Geffen_Records "Geffen
Records"), and digitally by Geffen on August 18, 2005.[123] The album contains
over 31 minutes of music coming from the movie, with most being composed by
Rota, along with a song from Coppola and one by Johnny Farrow and [Marty
Symes](/wiki/Marty_Symes "Marty Symes").[124][125][126]
[Allmusic](/wiki/Allmusic "Allmusic") gave the album five out of five stars,
with editor Zach Curd saying it is a "dark, looming, and elegant
soundtrack."[124] An editor for Filmtracks believed that Rota did a great job
of relating the music to the core aspects of the film, which the editor
believed to be "tradition, love, and fear."[126]

## Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Release")]

The world premiere for _The Godfather_ took place in New York City on March
14, 1972, almost three months after the planned release date of Christmas Day
in 1971,[127][128] with profits from the premiere donated to The Boys Club of
New York.[129] Before the film premiered, the film had already made $15
million from rentals from over 400 theaters.[36] The following day, the film
opened in New York at five theaters.[130][18][128] Next was [Los
Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles") at two theaters on March 22.[131]
_The Godfather_ was commercially released on March 24, 1972, throughout the
rest of the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States").[130][128]
The film reached 316 theaters around the country five days later.[132]

### Box office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Box office")]

_The Godfather_ was a [blockbuster](/wiki/Blockbuster_\(entertainment\)
"Blockbuster \(entertainment\)"), breaking many box office records to become
the [highest grossing film of 1972](/wiki/1972_in_film "1972 in film"). It
earned $81.5 million in [theatrical rentals](/wiki/Gross_rental "Gross
rental") in the USA & Canada during its initial release,[133] increasing its
earnings to $85.7 million through a reissue in 1973,[134] and including a
limited re-release in 1997 it ultimately earned an equivalent exhibition gross
of $135 million.[130] It displaced _[Gone with the
Wind](/wiki/Gone_with_the_Wind_\(film\) "Gone with the Wind \(film\)")_ to
claim the record as the top rentals earner, a position it would retain until
the release of _[Jaws](/wiki/Jaws_\(film\) "Jaws \(film\)")_ in
1975.[131][135] News articles at the time proclaimed it was the first film to
gross $100 million in North America,[131] but such accounts are erroneous
since this record in fact belongs to _[The Sound of
Music](/wiki/The_Sound_of_Music_\(film\) "The Sound of Music \(film\)")_ ,
released in 1965.[136] The film repeated its native success overseas, earning
in total an unprecedented $142 million in worldwide theatrical rentals, to
become the [highest net earner](/wiki/Timeline_of_highest-grossing_films
"Timeline of highest-grossing films").[137] Profits were so high for _The
Godfather_ that earnings for [Gulf & Western Industries,
Inc.](/wiki/Gulf%2BWestern "Gulf+Western"), which owned Paramount, jumped from
77 cents per share to $3.30 a share for the year, according to a _[Los Angeles
Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles Times")_ article, dated December
13, 1972.[131] To date, it has grossed between $245 million and $286 million
in worldwide box office receipts,[138] and adjusted for ticket price
[inflation](/wiki/Inflation "Inflation") in North America, ranks among the top
25 [highest-grossing films](/wiki/List_of_highest-
grossing_films_in_Canada_and_the_United_States#Adjusted_for_ticket-
price_inflation "List of highest-grossing films in Canada and the United
States").[139]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Critical response")]

_The Godfather_ has received critical acclaim and is seen as one of the most
influential films of all time, particularly in the
[gangster](/wiki/Gangster_film "Gangster film") genre.[140][141] On [Rotten
Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), the film has a 99% rating
based on 85 reviews with an average rating of 9.2/10 and the site's critical
consensus reads, " One of Hollywood's greatest critical and commercial
successes, _The Godfather_ gets everything right; not only did the movie
transcend expectations, it established new benchmarks for American
cinema".[142] [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic") assigned the film an
average score of 100% based on 14 reviews from mainstream critics, considered
to be "universal acclaim".[141] The film is ranked at the top of
[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic")'s top 100 list,[143] and is ranked
7th on [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes")' all-time
best list (100% "Certified Fresh").[144]

[Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") of the _[Chicago Sun
Times](/wiki/Chicago_Sun_Times "Chicago Sun Times")_ praised Coppola's efforts
to follow the storyline of the eponymous novel, the choice to set the film in
the same time as the novel, and the film's ability to "absorb" the viewer over
its three-hour run time.[145] While Ebert was mainly positive, he criticized
Brando's performance, saying his movements lacked "precision" and his voice
was "wheezy."[145] The _[Chicago Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Tribune "Chicago
Tribune")'_s [Gene Siskel](/wiki/Gene_Siskel "Gene Siskel") gave the film four
out of four stars, commenting that it was "very good."[146] _[The Village
Voice](/wiki/The_Village_Voice "The Village Voice")_ 's Andrew Sarris believed
Brando portrayed Vito Corleone well and that his character dominated each
scene it appeared in, but felt Puzo and Coppola had the character of Michael
Corleone too focused on revenge.[147] In addition, Sarris stated that Richard
Castellano, Robert Duvall, and James Caan were good in their respective
roles.[147]

Desson Howe of _[The Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The
Washington Post")_ called the film a "jewel" and wrote that Coppola deserves
most of the credit for the film.[148] Writing for _[The New York
Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ , [Vincent
Canby](/wiki/Vincent_Canby "Vincent Canby") felt that Coppola had created one
of the "most brutal and moving chronicles of American life" and went on to say
that it "transcends its immediate milieu and genre."[149] Director [Stanley
Kubrick](/wiki/Stanley_Kubrick "Stanley Kubrick") thought the film had the
best cast ever and could be the best movie ever made.[150] [Stanley
Kauffmann](/wiki/Stanley_Kauffmann "Stanley Kauffmann") of _The New Republic_
wrote negatively of the film in a contemporary review, claiming that Pacino
"rattles around in a part too demanding for him," while also criticizing
Brando's make-up and Rota's score.[151]

Previous mafia films had looked at the gangs from the perspective of an
outraged outsider.[152] In contrast, _The Godfather_ presents the gangster's
perspective of the Mafia as a response to corrupt society.[152] Although the
Corleone family is presented as immensely rich and powerful, no scenes depict
prostitution, gambling, loan sharking or other forms of racketeering.[153]
Some critics argue that the setting of a criminal counterculture allows for
unapologetic gender stereotyping, and is an important part of the film's
appeal ("You can act like a man!", Don Vito tells a weepy Johnny
Fontane).[154]

Remarking on the fortieth anniversary of the film's release, film critic [John
Podhoretz](/wiki/John_Podhoretz "John Podhoretz") praised _The Godfather_ as
"arguably _the_ great American work of popular art" and "the summa of all
great moviemaking before it".[155] Two years before, [Roger
Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") wrote in his journal that it "comes
closest to being a film everyone agrees... is unquestionably great."[156]

### Accolades[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Accolades")]

_The Godfather_ was nominated for seven awards at the [30th Golden Globe
Awards](/wiki/30th_Golden_Globe_Awards "30th Golden Globe Awards"): [Best
Picture – Drama](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Motion_Picture_-_Drama
"Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture - Drama"), [James
Caan](/wiki/James_Caan "James Caan") for [Best Supporting
Actor](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor_-_Motion_Picture
"Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor - Motion Picture"), [Al
Pacino](/wiki/Al_Pacino "Al Pacino") and [Marlon Brando](/wiki/Marlon_Brando
"Marlon Brando") for [Best Actor –
Drama](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Actor_-_Motion_Picture_Drama "Golden
Globe Award for Best Actor - Motion Picture Drama"), [Best
Score](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Original_Score "Golden Globe Award
for Best Original Score"), [Best
Director](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Director_-_Motion_Picture "Golden
Globe Award for Best Director - Motion Picture"), and [Best
Screenplay](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Screenplay "Golden Globe Award
for Best Screenplay").[157] When the winners were announced on January 28,
1973, the film had won the categories for: Best Screenplay, Best Director,
Best Actor - Drama, Best Original Score, and Best Picture – Drama.[158][159]
_The Godfather_ won a record five Golden Globes, which was not surpassed until
2017.[160]

Rota's score was also nominated for [Grammy Award for Best Original Score for
a Motion Picture or TV
Special](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Score_Soundtrack_for_Visual_Media "Grammy
Award for Best Score Soundtrack for Visual Media") at the [15th Grammy
Awards](/wiki/15th_Grammy_Awards "15th Grammy Awards").[161][162] Rota was
announced the winner of the category on March 3 at the Grammys' ceremony in
[Nashville, Tennessee](/wiki/Nashville,_Tennessee "Nashville,
Tennessee").[161][162]

When the nominations for the [45th Academy Awards](/wiki/45th_Academy_Awards
"45th Academy Awards") were revealed on February 12, 1973, _The Godfather_ was
nominated for eleven awards.[163][164] The nominations were for: [Best
Picture](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture "Academy Award for Best
Picture"), [Best Costume Design](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Costume_Design
"Academy Award for Best Costume Design"), Marlon Brando for [Best
Actor](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Actor "Academy Award for Best Actor"),
[Mario Puzo](/wiki/Mario_Puzo "Mario Puzo") and [Francis Ford
Coppola](/wiki/Francis_Ford_Coppola "Francis Ford Coppola") for [Best Adapted
Screenplay](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Adapted_Screenplay "Academy Award for
Best Adapted Screenplay"), Pacino, Caan, and [Robert
Duvall](/wiki/Robert_Duvall "Robert Duvall") for [Best Supporting
Actor](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor "Academy Award for Best
Supporting Actor"), [Best Film
Editing](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Film_Editing "Academy Award for Best
Film Editing"), [Nino Rota](/wiki/Nino_Rota "Nino Rota") for [Best Original
Score](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score "Academy Award for Best
Original Score"), Coppola for [Best
Director](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Director "Academy Award for Best
Director"), and [Best Sound](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Sound "Academy Award
for Best Sound").[163][164][165] Upon further review of Rota's [love theme
from _The
Godfather_](/wiki/Speak_Softly_Love_\(Love_Theme_from_The_Godfather\) "Speak
Softly Love \(Love Theme from The Godfather\)"), the Academy found that Rota
had used a similar score in [Eduardo De Filippo](/wiki/Eduardo_De_Filippo
"Eduardo De Filippo")'s 1958 comedy _[Fortunella](/wiki/Fortunella_\(film\)
"Fortunella \(film\)")_.[166][167][168] This led to re-balloting, where
members of the music branch chose from six films: _The Godfather_ and the five
films that had been on the shortlist for best original dramatic score but did
not get nominated. [John Addison](/wiki/John_Addison "John Addison")'s score
for _Sleuth_ won this new vote, and thus replaced Rota's score on the official
list of nominees.[169] Going into the awards ceremony, _The Godfather_ was
seen as the favorite to take home the most awards.[158] From the nominations
that _The Godfather_ had remaining, it only won three of the Academy Awards:
Best Actor, Best Adapted Screenplay, and Best Picture.[165][170]

Brando, who had also not attended the Golden Globes ceremony two months
earlier,[168][171] boycotted the Academy Awards ceremony and refused to accept
the Oscar, becoming the second actor to refuse a Best Actor award after
[George C. Scott](/wiki/George_C._Scott "George C. Scott") in
[1970](/wiki/43rd_Academy_Awards "43rd Academy Awards").[172][173] Brando sent
American Indian Rights activist [Sacheen
Littlefeather](/wiki/Sacheen_Littlefeather "Sacheen Littlefeather") in his
place, to announce at the awards podium Brando's reasons for declining the
award which were based on his objection to the depiction of American Indians
by Hollywood and television.[172][173][174] In addition, Pacino boycotted the
ceremony. He was insulted at being nominated for the Academy Award for Best
Supporting Actor award, noting that he had more screen time than his co-star
and Best Actor winner Brando and thus he should have received an Academy Award
nomination for Best Actor.[175]

_The Godfather_ had five nominations for awards at the [26th British Academy
Film Awards](/wiki/26th_British_Academy_Film_Awards "26th British Academy Film
Awards").[176] The nominees were: Pacino for [Most Promising
Newcomer](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Newcomer "BAFTA Award for Best
Newcomer"), Rota for the [Anthony Asquith Award for Film
Music](/wiki/Anthony_Asquith_Award_for_Film_Music "Anthony Asquith Award for
Film Music"), Duvall for [Best Supporting
Actor](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Actor_in_a_Supporting_Role "BAFTA Award for
Best Actor in a Supporting Role"), and Brando for [Best
Actor](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Actor_in_a_Leading_Role "BAFTA Award for
Best Actor in a Leading Role"), the film's costume designer Anna Hill
Johnstone for [Best Costume Design](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Costume_Design
"BAFTA Award for Best Costume Design").[176] All of _The Godfather '_s
nominations failed to win except for Rota.[176]

## Cinematic
influence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Cinematic influence")]

Although many [films about gangsters](/wiki/Gangster_film "Gangster film")
preceded _The Godfather_ , Coppola's heavy infusion of Italian culture and
stereotypes, and his portrayal of mobsters as characters of considerable
psychological depth and complexity was unprecedented.[196] Coppola took it
further with _The Godfather Part II_ , and the success of those two films,
critically, artistically and financially, opened the doors for numerous other
depictions of Italian Americans as mobsters, including films such as [Martin
Scorsese](/wiki/Martin_Scorsese "Martin Scorsese")'s
_[Goodfellas](/wiki/Goodfellas "Goodfellas")_ and TV series such as [David
Chase](/wiki/David_Chase "David Chase")'s _[The Sopranos](/wiki/The_Sopranos
"The Sopranos")_. A comprehensive study of Italian American culture on film,
conducted from 1996 to 2001 by the Italic Institute of America,[197] showed
that close to 300 movies featuring Italian Americans as mobsters (mostly
fictitious) have been produced since _The Godfather_ , an average of nine per
year.[198]

### Popular culture and
legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Popular culture and legacy")]

_The Godfather_ epic, encompassing the original trilogy and the additional
footage Coppola incorporated later, is by now thoroughly integrated into
American life and, together with a succession of mob-theme imitators, has led
to a highly stereotyped concept of Italian American culture. The first film
had the largest impact and, unlike any film before it, its depiction of
Italians who immigrated to the United States in the early decades of the 20th
century is perhaps attributable to the Italian American director, presenting
his own understanding of their experience. The films explain through their
action the integration of fictional Italian American criminals into American
society. Though the story is set in the period of mass immigration to the
U.S., it is rooted in the specific circumstances of the Corleones, a family
that lives outside of the law. Although some critics have refashioned the
Corleone story into one of universality of immigration, other critics have
posited that it leads the viewer to identify organized crime with Italian
American culture. Released in a period of intense national cynicism and self-
criticism, the American film struck a chord about the dual identities inherent
in a nation of immigrants.[199] _The Godfather_ increased Hollywood's negative
portrayals of immigrant Italians in the aftermath of the film and was a
recruiting tool for organized crime.[200]

The concept of a mafia "Godfather" was an invention of Mario Puzo's and the
film's effect was to add the fictional nomenclature to the language.
Similarly, Don Vito Corleone's unforgettable "I'm gonna make him an offer he
can't refuse"—voted the second-most memorable line in cinema history in [AFI's
100 Years... 100 Movie Quotes](/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years..._100_Movie_Quotes
"AFI's 100 Years... 100 Movie Quotes") by the [American Film
Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American Film Institute")—was
adopted by actual gangsters.[201] In the French novel _[Le Père
Goriot](/wiki/Le_P%C3%A8re_Goriot "Le Père Goriot")_ , [Honoré de
Balzac](/wiki/Honor%C3%A9_de_Balzac "Honoré de Balzac") wrote of
[Vautrin](/wiki/Vautrin "Vautrin") telling Eugene: "In that case I will make
you an offer that no one would decline."[202]

Real-life gangsters responded enthusiastically to the film, with many of them
feeling it was a portrayal of how they were supposed to act.[203] [Salvatore
"Sammy the Bull" Gravano](/wiki/Sammy_Gravano "Sammy Gravano"), the former
underboss in the [Gambino crime family](/wiki/Gambino_crime_family "Gambino
crime family"),[204] stated: "I left the movie stunned ... I mean I floated
out of the theater. Maybe it was fiction, but for me, then, that was our life.
It was incredible. I remember talking to a multitude of guys, [made
guys](/wiki/Made_man "Made man"), who felt exactly the same way." According to
[Anthony Fiato](/wiki/Anthony_Fiato "Anthony Fiato") after seeing the film,
[Patriarca crime family](/wiki/Patriarca_crime_family "Patriarca crime
family") members Paulie Intiso and Nicky Giso altered their speech patterns
closer to that of Vito Corleone's.[205] Intiso would frequently swear and use
poor grammar; but after the movie came out, he started to articulate and
philosophize more.[205]

### Television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Television")]

[John Belushi](/wiki/John_Belushi "John Belushi"), appearing in a _[Saturday
Night Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live "Saturday Night Live")_ sketch as Vito
Corleone in a therapy session expressing his inner feelings towards the
[Tattaglia Family](/wiki/Tattaglia_Family "Tattaglia Family"), says, "Also,
they shot my son Santino 56 times".[206]

In the television show _[The Sopranos](/wiki/The_Sopranos "The Sopranos")_ ,
[Tony Soprano](/wiki/Tony_Soprano "Tony Soprano")'s topless bar is named Bada
Bing, echoing the line in _The Godfather_ when Sonny Corleone says, "You've
gotta get up close like this and bada-bing! You blow their brains all over
your nice Ivy League suit."[207]

The film has been [parodied](/wiki/Parody "Parody") several times on the
[animated television series](/wiki/Animated_television_series "Animated
television series") _[The Simpsons](/wiki/The_Simpsons "The Simpsons")_. In
the [season three](/wiki/The_Simpsons_\(season_3\) "The Simpsons \(season
3\)") episode "[Lisa's Pony](/wiki/Lisa%27s_Pony "Lisa's Pony")" Lisa wakes up
to find a horse in her bed and starts screaming. The music and the scene
itself resemble the famous "horse's head" scene in The Godfather. In the
[season four](/wiki/The_Simpsons_\(season_4\) "The Simpsons \(season 4\)")
episode "[Mr. Plow](/wiki/Mr._Plow "Mr. Plow")", the scene in which Sonny
Corleone is shot at the tollbooth is mimicked when [Bart
Simpson](/wiki/Bart_Simpson "Bart Simpson") is pelted with
snowballs.[208][209] The scene is again parodied in the [season
sixteen](/wiki/The_Simpsons_\(season_16\) "The Simpsons \(season 16\)")
episode "[All's Fair in Oven War](/wiki/All%27s_Fair_in_Oven_War "All's Fair
in Oven War")", which includes James Caan as himself in a guest voice role. In
the [season eighteen](/wiki/The_Simpsons_\(season_18\) "The Simpsons \(season
18\)") episode "[The Mook, the Chef, the Wife and Her
Homer](/wiki/The_Mook,_the_Chef,_the_Wife_and_Her_Homer "The Mook, the Chef,
the Wife and Her Homer")", the film's final scene is mimicked with a door
being closed on [Lisa Simpson](/wiki/Lisa_Simpson "Lisa Simpson").[210]

## Home media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Home media")]

The theatrical version of _The Godfather_ debuted on American network
television on November 16, 1974, on [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC"), and again two days
later, with only minor edits.[211] The television airings attracted a large
audience and helped generate anticipation for the upcoming sequel.[211] The
next year, Coppola created _[The Godfather Saga](/wiki/The_Godfather_Saga "The
Godfather Saga")_ expressly for American television in a release that combined
_The Godfather_ and _The Godfather Part II_ with unused footage from those two
films in a chronological telling that toned down the violent, sexual, and
profane material for its [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") debut on November 18,
1977.[212] In 1981, Paramount released the _Godfather Epic_ boxed set, which
also told the story of the first two films in chronological order, again with
additional scenes, but not redacted for broadcast sensibilities.[212] _The
Godfather Trilogy_ was released in 1992, in which the films are fundamentally
in a chronological order.[213]

_The Godfather Family: A Look Inside_ was a 73-minute documentary released in
1991.[214] Directed by Jeff Warner, the film featured some behind the scenes
content from all three films, interviews with the actors, and screen
tests.[214] _The Godfather DVD Collection_ was released on October 9, 2001, in
a package that contained all three films—each with a commentary track by
Coppola—and a bonus disc containing _The Godfather Family: A Look
Inside_.[215] The DVD also held a Corleone family tree, a "Godfather"
timeline, and footage of the Academy Award acceptance speeches.[215]

### _The Godfather: The Coppola
Restoration_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: The Godfather: The Coppola Restoration")]

During the film's original theatrical release, the original negatives were
worn down due to the reel being printed so much to meet demand.[216][217] In
addition, the duplicate negative was lost in Paramount archives.[217] In 2006
Coppola contacted [Steven Spielberg](/wiki/Steven_Spielberg "Steven
Spielberg")—whose studio [DreamWorks](/wiki/DreamWorks "DreamWorks") had
recently been bought out by Paramount—about restoring _The
Godfather_.[216][217] [Robert A. Harris](/wiki/Robert_A._Harris "Robert A.
Harris") was hired to oversee the restoration of _The Godfather_ and its two
sequels, with the film's cinematographer Willis participating in the
restoration.[218][219] Work began in November 2006 by repairing the negatives
so they could go through a digital scanner to produce high resolution 4K
files.[216][217] If a negative were damaged and discolored, work was done
digitally to restore it to its original look.[216][217] After a year and a
half of working on the restoration, the project was complete.[217] Paramount
called the finished product _The Godfather: The Coppola Restoration_ and
released it to the public on September 23, 2008, on both DVD and [Blu-ray
Disc](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc").[218][219] Dave Kehr of _The New York
Times_ believed the restoration brought back the "golden glow of their
original theatrical screenings".[218] As a whole, the restoration of the film
was well received by critics and Coppola.[216][217][218][219][220] _The
Godfather: The Coppola Restoration_ contains several new special features that
play in high definition, along with additional scenes.[220]

### Video game[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Video game")]

Main article: [The Godfather (2006 video
game)](/wiki/The_Godfather_\(2006_video_game\) "The Godfather \(2006 video
game\)")

The game is based upon this film and tells the story of an original character,
[Aldo Trapani](/wiki/Aldo_Trapani "Aldo Trapani"), whose rise through the
ranks of the Corleone family intersects with the plot of the film on numerous
occasions.[221][222] Duvall, Caan, and Brando supplied voiceovers and their
likenesses,[223] but Pacino did not.[223] Francis Ford Coppola openly voiced
his disapproval of the game.[224]

section: Notes")]

  1. **Jump up ^** Sources disagree on the date where Paramount confirmed their intentions to make Mario Puzo's novel _The Godfather_ into a feature-length film. Harlan Lebo's work states that the announcement came in January 1969,[9] while Jenny Jones' book puts the date of the announcement three months after the novel's publication, in June 1969.[11]
  2. **Jump up ^** Sources disagree on both the amount of the original budget and the final budget. The starting budget has been recorded as $1 million,[16] $2 million,[14][36][37][9] and $2.5 million,[18][38] while the final budget has been named at $5 million,[26] $6 million,[18][39] and $6.5 million.[36][40]

qa.question: who played the godfather in the movie the godfather
